text: " the weather is clearing a bit , " he told me . " i have high hopes . after breakfast we 'll make our way ashore and choose an observation post . "

m de treville received him as if he had seen him that same morning ; only , when pressing his hand a little more warmly than usual , he informed him that the company of dessessart was on duty at the louvre , and that he might repair at once to his post .
the colonists were on the qui vive , and did not leave their post at the chimneys .
" i was to take your dispatches , written or verbal , and return by post ; and when he shall know what you have done , he will advise what you have to do . "
the brig immediately sent a second ball on the post betrayed by the smoke , but without any other result than that of splintering the rock .

ned land made his way to his post . the furnaces were urged into greater activity ; our propeller did forty - three revolutions per minute , and steam shot from the valves . heaving the log , we verified that the abraham lincoln was going at the rate of 18.5 miles per hour .

at the name of lord de winter , who was known to be one of his grace ’s most intimate friends , the officer of the post gave orders to let felton pass , who , besides , wore the uniform of a naval officer .
what a chase ! no , i ca n't describe the excitement that shook my very being . ned land stayed at his post , harpoon in hand . several times the animal let us approach .

" listen , " said the young man to the sentinel . " on no pretense leave the door , for you know that last night my lord punished a soldier for having quit his post for an instant , although i , during his absence , watched in his place . "
" then it is understood , " said d’artagnan ; " you would rather be killed than desert your post ? "
the officer who commanded the post of the red cross was sent for , and by successive inquiries they learned that athos was then lodged in the fort l’eveque .
i leaped up on the rock ; my uncle lightly followed , while our hunter remained at his post , like a man too wise ever to be astonished .
